rows.title: How can I read inputs as numbers?

77:
<pre class="lang-py s-code-block"><code class="hljs language-python">n=<span class="hljs-built_in">int</span>(<span class="hljs-built_in">input</span>())
<span class="hljs-keyword">for</span> i <span class="hljs-keyword">in</span> <span class="hljs-built_in">range</span>(n):
    n=<span class="hljs-built_in">input</span>()
    n=<span class="hljs-built_in">int</span>(n)
    arr1=<span class="hljs-built_in">list</span>(<span class="hljs-built_in">map</span>(<span class="hljs-built_in">int</span>,<span class="hljs-built_in">input</span>().split()))
</code></pre>

<p>the for loop shall run 'n' number of times . the second 'n' is the length of the array.
the last statement maps the integers to a list and takes input in space separated form .
you can also return the array at the end of for loop.</p>

<pre class="lang-py s-code-block"><code class="hljs language-python"><span class="hljs-keyword">def</span> <span class="hljs-title function_">dbz</span>():
    <span class="hljs-keyword">try</span>:
        r = raw_input(<span class="hljs-string">"Enter number:"</span>)
        <span class="hljs-keyword">if</span> r.isdigit():
            i = <span class="hljs-built_in">int</span>(raw_input(<span class="hljs-string">"Enter divident:"</span>))
            d = <span class="hljs-built_in">int</span>(r)/i
            <span class="hljs-built_in">print</span> <span class="hljs-string">"O/p is -:"</span>,d
        <span class="hljs-keyword">else</span>:
            <span class="hljs-built_in">print</span> <span class="hljs-string">"Not a number"</span>
    <span class="hljs-keyword">except</span> Exception ,e:
        <span class="hljs-built_in">print</span> <span class="hljs-string">"Program halted incorrect data entered"</span>,<span class="hljs-built_in">type</span>(e)
dbz()

Or 

num = <span class="hljs-built_in">input</span>(<span class="hljs-string">"Enter Number:"</span>)<span class="hljs-comment">#"input" will accept only numbers</span>
</code></pre>

<p>While in your example, <code>int(input(...))</code> does the trick in any case, <code>python-future</code>'s <a href="http://python-future.org/compatible_idioms.html#input" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>builtins.input</code></a> is worth consideration since that makes sure your code works for both Python 2 and 3 <em>and</em> disables Python2's default behaviour of <code>input</code> trying to be "clever" about the input data type (<code>builtins.input</code> basically just behaves like <code>raw_input</code>).</p>
